conclusion: To determine the maximum distance between Car A and Car B between the two instances when they are side by side, we need to analyze their positions as functions of time.
The position \( s(t) \) can be found by integrating the velocity \( v(t) \).
Car A has a constant velocity of 40 m/s from \( t = 0 \) to \( t = 30 \) seconds.

premise: Car A has a constant velocity of 40 m/s from \( t = 0 \) to \( t = 30 \) seconds.
conclusion: The position function for Car A is \( s_A(t) = 40t \) for \( 0 \leq t \leq 30 \).
Car B has a constant velocity of 0 m/s from \( t = 0 \) to \( t = 10 \) seconds.
Car B accelerates linearly from 0 m/s to 40 m/s from \( t = 10 \) to \( t = 20 \) seconds.
Car B maintains a constant velocity of 40 m/s from \( t = 20 \) to \( t = 30 \) seconds.

conclusion: The position function for Car B from \( t = 10 \) to \( t = 20 \) is \( s_B(t) = 20(t - 10)^2 \).

premise: Car B maintains a constant velocity of 40 m/s from \( t = 20 \) to \( t = 30 \) seconds.
conclusion: The position function for Car B from \( t = 20 \) to \( t = 30 \) is \( s_B(t) = 40(t - 20) + s_B(20) \).

The position function for Car B from \( t = 20 \) to \( t = 30 \) is \( s_B(t) = 40(t - 20) + s_B(20) \).
conclusion: The position function for Car B from \( t = 20 \) to \( t = 30 \) is \( s_B(t) = 40t + 1200 \).
